 UPDATE      The Cox News Service spot news budget for Wednesday, August 4,
1999.
      c.1998 Cox News Service

   Eds: Adds: SHOOTINGS-MURDERS, SHOOTINGS-GRADY, F-22, SCOT-GOLF,
NASHVILLE-VOTE; updates: SHOOTINGS-YUSEF;

   deletes: ATLANTA-MURDERS

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   INTERNATIONAL

   SCOT-GOLF _Opponents of more golf course resort development in
St. Andrews, Scotland, backed away from launching a legal challenge
to Chateau Elan's plans for a hotel, two courses and a conference
center on what used to be Kingask farm. Owners of the Georgia
winery-golf resort can continue their development, the town's
community council decided, even though many there hoped to prevent
the quaint university town from being turned into a tacky golf
theme park. (Roughton, Cox News Service)

   WASHINGTON

   F22 _ WASHINGTON _The Air Force chief of staff maintains that
the House decision to delete $1.8 billion earmarked for the F-22
will be reversed by the full Congress. But Rep. Jerry Lewis
(R-Calif.), chairman of the House defense appropriations
subcommittee, says he hasn't changed his mind. Sen. Ted Stevens,
though, says no appropriations will come to the floor without money
for the F-22. (Foskett, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MATURE-SEX _ WASHINGTON _ AARP's Modern Maturity magazine
releases a study about the sexual attitudes and behavior of
Americans 45 and older. (Lipman, Cox News Service). 22.

   EDs: Moving Monday in advance in (w) Washington and (l)
lifestyle categories.

   RACE-LAW-SCHOOL _ WASHINGTON _ The Civil Rights Project of
Harvard University releases a report on ''Diversity and Legal
Education,'' a new study supporting the benefits of diversity.
(Mollison, Cox News Service). 20.

   ANTHRAX _ WASHINGTON _ Reps. Walter Jones, R-N.C., and Benjamin
Gilman, R-N.Y., hold a news conference to discuss efforts to halt
the Department of Defense's mandatory anthrax vaccine program.
(Moscoso, Cox News Service). 18.

   SUGAR _ WASHINGTON _ The Center for Science in the Public
Interest holds a news conference to discuss the impact of eating
too much sugar and to announce the filing of a petition with the
Food and Drug Administration requiring specific nutrition labeling
of ''added sugars'' in foods. (Hall, Cox News Service). 18.

   TECH-SENATE _ WASHINGTON _ Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott and
Republican senators involved in tech policy issue a new challenge
to President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore on their high-tech
efforts and to release the majority agenda. (Glass, Cox News
Service). 18.

   EDs: Moving in (w) Washington and (f) financial categories.

   ATLANTA MASS KILLINGS

   SHOOTINGS-MURDERS _ ATLANTA _ The mass killings that have marred
July in this city obviously have prompted the homicide rate to
climb by nine, for the year to date. APD Chief Harvard says there
is nothing anyone can do to prevent someone from going off and
killing nine people. However last year, APD recieved a $76,000
federal grant to study homicides in Atlanta and how police could
prevent them by finding out more about where they occurred, who the
victim/suspects were, motives, etc. Barton's spree and where it
erupted does not fit the typical profile of homicide in Atlanta,
and Barton does not fit the profile of the typical killer. (Longa,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   w/SHOOTINGS-GRADY _ ATLANTA _ Is no place safe? Even as four men
wounded in Thursday's rampage in Buckhead were struggling to
recover in hospital beds upstairs, a security guard shot a man
brandishing a gun near the pharmacy at Grady Memorial Hospital
Tuesday morning. Kenneth Gay is in critical condition. Gay's family
was bringing him in with hopes of having a psychiatric evaluation,
but when they reached the metal detectors at the entrance to the
13th-floor pysch unit Gay became agitated and pulled out a gun. He
jumped in an elevator, getting off at the first floor where he was
confront by a retired APD officer now working at the public
hospital. Grady chaplains quickly responded by trying to buffer the
Buckhead victims from any knowledge of what was going on near the
hospital's Pratt St. entrance. Employees and others all rattled by
a shooting so soon after Mark Barton's rampage. (Longa, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   SHOOTINGS-YUSEF _ Yusef Liberzon, 39, became a day trader
because he wanted to learn computers and get away from being a taxi
driver _ which was too dangerous for too little money, friends
said. Liberzon, a Russian immigrant from Kiev, was shot in the head
by Mark Barton and has undergone surgery to remove the bullet and a
good portion of his brain. Today (8-4), doctors will see if there
is any sign of hope _ by checking brain activity. Liberzon, a U.S.
citizen after nine years, is the sole support for his wife and his
mother. His wife is a citizen, but his mother is not _ and has no
papers. Friends and family worry about his family _ who speaks no
English _ and what will become of his mother. (Lore, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   NATIONAL

   BLACK-BEAR _ WASHINGTON _ A coalition of environmental groups
announced Tuesday they were suing the U.S. Fish and Wildlife
Service for removing the Florida black bear from the list of
endangered species. (Nesmith, Cox News Service).

   NASHVILLE-VOTE _ NASHVILLE _ Voters head to the polls Thursday
to elect a new mayor to succeed popular Mayor Phil Bredesen, but
most observers predict the non-partisan race involving nine
candidates will require a run-off vote in September. The leading
candidate in local polls is two-time former mayor Richard Fulton,
who also is a former U.S. Congressman. At least one analyst
believes turnout on Thursday will be low.

   `One reason is that things are going well,

   ` said M. Lee Smith, a Nashville political analyst. The crime
rate has dropped in Nashville. School funding increased in
Bredesen's term. The Tennessee Titans begin their inaugural season
in August in a new $290 million stadium downtown. (DuBose, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   NEWCOPS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Among police departments in Ohio's
largest cities, Dayton has the whitest force with 88 percent. For
years, the Dayton Police Department has struggled with its facade,
attempting to make it more closely represent the 40 percent black
people who live in the Gem City. But in the past decade, the
department's racial makeup has changed little. All this is splashed
against a backdrop of celebration as Dayton's 90th recruit class
graduates tonight, adding three black men, seven females, one
Native American man and 10 white males to the force. (Vasconez,
Dayton Daily News) MOVED.

   Y2K-POLL _ More than half of Atlantans are concerned that
computers might stall when the Times Square ball rings in the year
2000 and a third are preparing by stockpiling food, water or other
supplies _ just in case, according to a new poll by The Atlanta
Journal-Constitution. (Hendrick, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   POLITICAL

   BRADLEY _ Tapping into fresh doubts about Vice President Gore's
ability win the general election, former senator Bill Bradley is
chipping away at the aura of invincibility that once surrounded
Gore's campaign for the Democratic nomination. The former NBA star
has exceeded all expectations. He's attracting millions in
financial support, plenty of big name endorsements and national
media attention. With nearly as much money in the bank as Gore and
a reputation for frugality, Bradley has erased doubts that his
campaign won't be able to go the distance with Gore in Iowa, New
Hampshire and beyond. (Foskett, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 35.

   QUAYLE _ WASHINGTON _ Republican presidential candidate Dan
Quayle addresses a National Press Club luncheon on his presidential
campaign and values. (Lipman, Cox News Service). 18.

   EDs: Moving in (W) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   BUSH-RICHARDS _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Former Gov. Ann Richards, the
first Democrat to lose to him, says the best way to go after George
W. Bush is not to. ``I wouldn't pay any attention to the
opponent,'' Richards said when he asked for her advice on how to
run against Bush. As Bush looks more and more like the inevitable
GOP nominee, the Democrats are scrambling for the most effective
way of running against him. So far, the Gore camp has adopted a
relatively low- key, subtle approach. But the Democratic National
Committee, ignoring Richards advice and perhaps foreshadowing
what's to come, is mounting a full-frontal assault. A look at the
Democratic strategy for beating Bush, an early front-runner in this
earliest of election campaigns. (Herman, Austin American-Statesman)
MOVED.
